Tulum

Where ancient Mayan ruins meet bohemian beach paradise

Quick Facts About Tulum

Best Time to Visit
November to April
Average Temperature
28°C (82°F) year-round
Known For
Mayan ruins, cenotes, eco-hotels, yoga retreats
Airport Code
CUN (Cancún)

About Tulum

Tulum is Mexico's most photogenic destination, featuring dramatic clifftop Mayan ruins overlooking the Caribbean Sea, pristine beaches, mystical cenotes for swimming and diving, and a unique collection of eco-chic boutique hotels. It's the Yucatán's premier blend of ancient history, natural beauty, and bohemian culture.

Once a walled Mayan city that served as a major trading port, Tulum is now one of Mexico's most captivating destinations. The archaeological site, perched dramatically on 12-meter cliffs above the turquoise Caribbean, is the only Mayan ruin overlooking the sea—making it perhaps the most photographed archaeological site in the Americas. Beyond the ruins, Tulum has evolved into a unique destination that defies categorization. The beach road (Zona Hotelera) stretches for several kilometers, lined with boutique eco-hotels, yoga retreats, and farm-to-table restaurants—many without electricity, running on solar power and lit by candlelight. It's a place where wellness, sustainability, and barefoot luxury converge. The surrounding area offers some of the Yucatán's most spectacular cenotes—sacred sinkholes connected by underground rivers that were central to Mayan cosmology. Today, these crystal-clear pools offer magical swimming and diving experiences. Whether you're exploring ancient history, lounging on pristine beaches, or seeking spiritual renewal, Tulum delivers an experience unlike anywhere else in the Caribbean.

Where to Stay in Tulum

From luxury resorts to boutique hotels, find the perfect accommodation for your Tulum vacation.

  • Tulum

    ★ {{#if this.category}}

    Iconic treehouse-style resort with no electricity, WiFi, or shoes allowed. Stunning wooden architecture, clifftop spa, and pure digital detox. The ultimate Tulum experience.

  • Tulum

    ★ {{#if this.category}}

    Sophisticated beachfront resort with stunning suites, world-class spa, and excellent restaurant. Modern luxury with Tulum bohemian spirit.

  • Tulum

    ★ {{#if this.category}}

    Bohemian-chic hotel with globally-inspired design, excellent restaurant, and spiritual programming including sound healing and yoga.

  • Tulum

    ★ {{#if this.category}}

    Art hotel in Pablo Escobar's former beach mansion, now featuring contemporary art collection and one of Tulum's best beach clubs.

Where to Eat in Tulum

Experience the best of Mexican cuisine and international dining in Tulum.

  • Farm-to-Table

    Hartwood

    The restaurant that put Tulum on the culinary map. Open-fire cooking with daily-changing menu based on local ingredients. No reservations - arrive early or late.

    $$$$
  • Contemporary Mexican

    Arca

    Wood-fired tasting menus in a stunning jungle setting. One of Mexico's most acclaimed restaurants, blending tradition with innovation.

    $$$$
  • Mexican Street Food

    Taquería Honorio

    Legendary local taquería in the pueblo serving some of the best tacos in the Yucatán. Carnitas and cochinita pibil are the stars.

    $
  • Vegan/Raw

    Raw Love

    Popular plant-based café on the beach road with colorful smoothie bowls, raw desserts, and excellent coffee. The Instagram aesthetic is strong.

    $$
View all restaurants in Tulum →

Neighborhoods in Tulum

Explore the unique character of each neighborhood and find the perfect area for your stay.

  • Tulum

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    The famous beach road lined with eco-chic boutique hotels, yoga studios, and barefoot-luxury restaurants. Many properties run on solar power and candlelight. This is the Tulum of Instagram dreams.

  • Tulum

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    The authentic Mexican town where locals live, featuring affordable restaurants, local markets, and genuine culture. A world away from the beach zone prices and crowds.

  • Tulum

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    The northern stretch of beach road closer to the ruins, featuring some of the best beaches and more established hotels. Easier access to the archaeological site.

  • Tulum

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Newer residential/tourist development between the pueblo and beach zone with condos, co-living spaces, and a growing restaurant scene. Popular with digital nomads.

{{/if}}

Day Trips from Tulum

Explore the surrounding region with these popular excursions.

  • Tulum

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Explore multiple cenotes in one day. Popular routes include Gran Cenote, Cenote Calavera, and Cenote Dos Ojos. Each offers unique swimming and diving experiences.

  • Tulum

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    UNESCO-protected reserve with boat tours through mangroves, Mayan canals, and Caribbean coastline. Spot dolphins, manatees, and countless bird species.

  • Tulum

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    Climb the tallest pyramid in the Yucatán and explore this vast jungle-set Mayan city by bicycle. Less crowded than Chichén Itzá.

  • Tulum

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    One of the New Seven Wonders of the World. See El Castillo pyramid and experience Mayan history at its most monumental.

{{/if}}

Practical Information

Getting There

Fly into Cancún International Airport (CUN), then it's about 1.5-2 hours to Tulum by car, shuttle, or ADO bus ($15-20 USD). Private transfers cost $100-150 USD. Tulum has a small airport for private planes only.

Getting Around

Bikes are king in Tulum - rent one for $10-15/day. The beach road is bikeable end-to-end. Taxis charge fixed rates ($5-10 within town, $15-20 to beach zone). Rent a car for day trips to cenotes and archaeological sites.

Safety Information

Tulum is generally safe for tourists. Watch your belongings on the beach. Use authorized taxis or have hotels call them at night. The beach road is dark at night - use a light. Cenotes have no lifeguards - swim at your own risk.

Frequently Asked Questions About Tulum

What is the best time to visit Tulum?
November to April offers the best weather with less rain and comfortable temperatures. The peak season (December-March) has the best weather but highest prices. Avoid September-October for hurricane season. Summer can be hot with afternoon showers and sargassum seaweed on beaches.
Should I stay on the beach or in town (pueblo)?
Beach zone offers the iconic Tulum experience with eco-hotels and stunning beaches, but at premium prices with limited WiFi. Pueblo is authentic, budget-friendly, and 10 minutes by bike from the beach. Many visitors split their stay between both areas.
How do I get around Tulum?
Bikes are the most popular way to get around - most hotels rent them. The beach zone has one main road, and pueblo is compact. Taxis work for longer distances. Rent a car for day trips to cenotes, Cobá, or Sian Ka'an.
Is Tulum expensive?
Tulum's beach zone is expensive by Mexico standards - comparable to trendy US destinations. Budget travelers should stay in pueblo where you can find good hotels for $50-80/night and tacos for $2. Beach zone hotels start around $200-300/night and meals $40-80.
What's the sargassum (seaweed) situation?
Sargassum seaweed can affect beaches from May to September, varying by year. Hotels clean their beach sections, but open beaches may be affected. Check recent photos before booking summer trips. The seaweed doesn't affect cenotes.
Can I visit Tulum as a day trip from Cancún?
Yes, Tulum is about 1.5-2 hours from Cancún. Many tours combine the ruins with cenotes or beach time. However, to truly experience Tulum's bohemian beach vibe, at least 2-3 nights is recommended.
Is Tulum safe?
Tulum is generally safe for tourists. Use normal precautions: don't leave valuables on the beach, take authorized transportation at night, and be aware of your surroundings. The main tourist areas are well-patrolled.
Do I need to book cenotes in advance?
For popular cenotes like Gran Cenote and Dos Ojos, no reservation is needed - just show up. Arrive early morning (8-9am) for fewer crowds. Some private cenotes and cave diving experiences require advance booking.
